message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms and absence of pedal pulses on the right suggest arterial embolism. Smoking and hypertension are risk factors for atherosclerosis, but sudden onset is not typical of atherosclerotic narrowing. Arterial vasospasm or popliteal artery aneurysm are less likely causes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms, including pain, tingling, weakness, and absent pedal pulses on the affected leg suggest an acute arterial occlusion caused by an embolism. Risk factors such as smoking, diabetes, and hypertension increase the likelihood of arterial disease and embolic events. Arterial vasospasm, popliteal artery aneurysm, and atherosclerotic narrowing of the artery are less likely causes of the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms, including pain, tingling, and weakness, in addition to absent pedal pulses and a cool and pale right leg suggest that the most likely underlying cause is an arterial embolism. Atherosclerotic narrowing of the artery and arterial vasospasm would be more gradual and not present as suddenly. Popliteal artery aneurysm may be a possibility, but it is less likely than arterial embolism given the patient’s history and symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms, absence of pulses, and atherosclerotic risk factors suggest an arterial embolism as the most likely underlying cause. Arterial vasospasm and atherosclerotic narrowing of the artery may cause diminished pulses, but not the sudden onset of symptoms. Popliteal artery aneurysm usually presents with slow onset of symptoms over time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with sudden onset of pain, tingling sensation, and weakness in his right leg, with absent pedal pulses on the right. These symptoms are indicative of arterial embolism, which can occur from a blood clot or plaque dislodged from atherosclerotic plaque in the arterial wall. The fact that the patient has no history of claudication suggests that there was no previous decrease in blood flow to the leg due to atherosclerotic narrowing of the artery. Arterial vasospasm is less likely to cause sudden onset of symptoms, while popliteal artery aneurysm typically presents with a pulsatile mass in the popliteal fossa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms, absence of pulse, and risk factors like smoking and hypertension suggest arterial embolism. Atherosclerotic narrowing and popliteal artery aneurysm would present with more gradual symptoms, and arterial vasospasm would not result in absent pulses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain, tingling sensation, weakness, and absence of pedal pulse on the right indicate an arterial embolism. The patient also has risk factors for atherosclerosis, which can lead to embolism formation. Atherosclerotic narrowing of the artery would cause gradual onset of symptoms, while vasospasm and popliteal artery aneurysm would not cause such acute symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms, including pain, weakness, and tingling, along with the absent pedal pulses on the right, suggest an arterial embolism. Atherosclerosis narrowing of the artery usually develops gradually, so it's not as sudden. Arterial vasospasm and popliteal artery aneurysm are also unlikely to cause these specific symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with classic symptoms of acute limb ischemia, including sudden onset of pain, tingling, and weakness, as well as absent pedal pulses and coolness to touch in the affected limb. Arterial embolism, which is a sudden occlusion of a vessel due to a clot or other debris that travels from elsewhere in the body, is the most likely underlying cause of these symptoms. The patient's smoking history and diabetes also increase his risk for developing peripheral arterial disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain, tingling sensation, weakness, and absence of pedal pulses on the right suggest an arterial embolism. Other options like arterial vasospasm, popliteal artery aneurysm, and atherosclerotic narrowing would not present with sudden onset and absence of pedal pulses. The patient's smoking history and hypertension may increase the risk of atherosclerosis and subsequently arterial embolism.
